citation.article-title: Enterobacter cowanii sp. nov., a new species of the family Enterobacteriaceae.

p.s: Description of Enterobacter cowanii sp. nov.
Enterobacter cowanii (The specific name "cowanii" is derived from the surname of S. T. Cowan, an English bacteriologist, and honors him for his significant contributions to bacterial taxonomy)
Cells are Gram-negative, oxidase-negative, fermentative rods that are motile by peritrichous flagella.
The species conforms to the definition of the family Enterobacteriaceae.
Strains grow well on MacConkey agar and are facultatively anaerobic.
They give negative results in tests for the production of indole, urease, phenylalanine deaminase, lysine, and ornithine decarboxylases, arginine dihydrolase, and for the utilization of malonate.
They give positive reactions in Voges-Proskauer, citrate utilization, and esculin hydrolysis tests.
They ferment lactose, sucrose, raffinose, sorbitol, dulcitol, and salicin, but not inositol nor D-arabitol.
A complete description of E. cowanii is given in Table 2.
The G+C content of its DNA ranges from 52.5% to 53.6%.
The type strain of E. cowanii is 888-76 (JCM 10956).
It was isolated by blood culture from a patient with gastric cancer.
The phenotypic properties of the type strain are also shown in Table 2.
Of the nine strains studied, eight were isolated respectively from urine (4), sputum (2), blood (1), and pus (1), but their clinical significance is unknown.
It may also be found in foods.
